titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

p.hi: I spent the morning in writing letters and then in reading again
's chapters on the Cistercian Order in his "
vol V. The one writer's sympathies are strongly Protestant: the other's are strongly Catholick: but both are genuine scholars and write honestly. On the whole I think
's is the truest account of Medieval Monasticism.

, the Rector of Long newton, lunched here. He came to ask permission to resign his benefice, a permission which his face, horribly distorted by some dreadful operation, significantly justified. But he wants a pension, which will reduce the income of his successor to a woeful pittance.

gave another lesson in golf: but my performance is humiliating in its badness. There can be no doubt that the spectacle of a man of 64 essaying to learn a game which should be mastered in youth is ludicrous from one point of view, and pathetick from another!
